qas.question: Who spoke at the Philadelphia Convention about the potential chaos from not having judges be able to enforce laws?
What did George Mason state that judges could do to a law?
Who said that laws may be just, wise or dangerous?
What convention took place in the seventeenth century?

plausible_answers.text: "When its existence as law is denied, that existence cannot be proved by showing what are the qualities of a law."

qas.question: What position to Chief Justice Marshall take in the eighteenth century?
Who did George Mason say could not declare a law unconstitutional

context: <a1_0><b4_0>James Wilson<b4_0/><a1_0/> said during the <b5_0>Philadelphia Convention<b5_0/> in <a0_0>1787<a0_0/> that, "Laws may be unjust, may be unwise, may be dangerous, may be destructive; and yet not be so unconstitutional as to justify the Judges in refusing to give them effect." George Mason agreed that <b7_0>judges<b7_0/> "could <a3_0>declare an unconstitutional law void<a3_0/>. But with regard to every law, however unjust, oppressive or pernicious, which did not come plainly under this description, they would be under the necessity as judges to give it a free course." <a2_0>Chief Justice<a2_0/> John Marshall (joined by Justice Joseph Story) took a similar position in 1827: <b6_0>"When its existence as law is denied, that existence cannot be proved by showing what are the qualities of a law."
